title: Shocking pictures of dead animals killed in badger cull waiting to be burned
text:

Bags of dead badgers are lined up ready to be burnt - victims of the latest Government-backed cull.

Nearly 63,000 of the animals are being slaughtered in this year’s killing programme.

The bloody, lifeless creatures in these shocking images were blasted to death in the South West last month.

The photographs were taken in one of the centres where carcasses are stored before being incinerated.

The pictures were passed to the Mirror by the Badger Trust which is fighting to end the cull - and come as MPs prepare to hold a 90-minute Westminster Hall debate on Wednesday on the scheme.

(Image: Picture courtesy of Badger Trust)

Charity chief executive Dominic Dyer said: “This brutal and heartbreaking image of slaughtered badgers bagged up like rubbish to be burned and forgotten is being repeated night after night across the length and breadth of England.

“This systematic cruel slaughter of a protected species to appease the industrial farming lobby is little more than ecological vandalism and is a national disgrace.”

Supporters say killing badgers helps curb TB in cows, with badgers blamed for spreading the disease around the countryside, infecting cattle.

(Image: Picture courtesy of Badger Trust)

But opponents believe the cull is cruel and ineffective.

The Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs revealed last month which areas of England had been granted cull licences – with the annual bloodbath widened to 11 new areas.

Fresh zones have been setup in Avon, Cheshire, Cornwall, Staffordshire, Devon, Dorset, Hertfordshire and Wiltshire.

Culling is also continuing in Gloucestershire, Herefordshire, Somerset and Cumbria.

Mr Dyer added: “Thousands of badgers are being killed by a cruel controlled shooting method, which results in them taking over five minutes to die of multiple bullet wounds, blood loss and organ failure.

“The Government could kill every badger in England and TB would still remain in cattle herds, due to inaccurate TB testing methods, poor bio-security and cattle movement controls.”

Some 67,154 badgers have been killed in the mass culling scheme since 2013, mainly through shooting.

(Image: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

A total of 32,601 of the creatures were killed last year in 32 areas across Dorset, Cornwall, Devon, Gloucestershire, Herefordshire, Cheshire, Somerset, Wiltshire, Staffordshire and Cumbria, under the controversial scheme.

Last November, a Government-backed review into the cull called on farmers to toughen up controls to prevent TB spreading in their cattle.

A 138-page study said farmers should shoulder extra costs to protect their cows.

Supporters of the cull pointed to figures showing more than 33,000 cattle had to be slaughtered in 2017 England to control the disease, “causing devastation and distress for farmers and rural communities”.

Farming Minister George Eustice said in September: “Bovine TB remains the greatest animal health threat to the UK, costing taxpayers over £100million every year as well as causing devastation and distress for hard-working farmers and rural communities.

(Image: Daily Record)

“There is no single measure that will provide an answer to beating this disease.

“That is why we have always been committed to a multi-pronged approach including proactive badger control as well as other tools such as tighter cattle controls, improved bio-security and badger vaccination.”
